reviewText: some of life and love's ups and downs, inside and outs, a wistful comedy about a shmuck who destroys his marriage with a casual affair and thereby liberates his ex-wife into becoming an independent woman who go on with her life, while he tries to regain that which he had had and lost; Segal, Anspach, and Kristofferson perfect in their roles in this period piece (70's) but with lasting appeal. A woman's movie that appeals to consciousness-raised men as well, with love winning in the end, but between which parties? Ah, there's the rub. Enjoy SHALOM Alex
summary: Perhaps not for everyone, but for those who have experienced

reviewText: I always loved this movie, and, its director's witty, clever,and, most of all,unconventional style and script,so wonderfully depicting, a very realistic scenario of the Beverly Hills of almost (Oy vey!) 40 years ago!However,I think that, maybe, his very first film, one of the most popular,celebrated,and biggest box office's success ever, for a first time director's movie,"BOB&CAROL;&TED;&ALICE;",filmed in Los Angeles,in 1969,is probably,truly,the most remembered and accomplished, Mazursky's film, since it was not only displaying,one of the most authentic portrayal of a certain (presumably)liberated American's(or,shall I say,rather,LA,California? LOL)upper class,but,also, an incredibly funny,poignant,and truly memorable script,in a way, a bit like "Shampoo" (1975,excellent!)ended up being,a few years later,and, like the latter,with many great stars turns,from its great cast, including,here,one,quite emblematic,from lovely Natalie Wood,then delivering probably her best performances,ever!"Blume" is instead somewhat of a certainly even more "adult" film,indeed, in the sense that,its script is so perfectly dosed and calibrated, witty and insightful, and, the film's cinematic style, so innovative, and intense, while,always managing not to become only, a mere show off of the 1970's new film styles and characteristics,but,truly,almost embracing, while translating,as well, into Mazursky's very own personal,visionary cinematic language,through, all the(visible) love and admiration,he was carrying for some of the best European directors, a passion,this refined,intelligent,yet, somewhat unfortunate (in a way) director, was, at that time,feeling and cultivating,and even strongly imposing into the US Markets! And,in fact, beside,being almost a 'stalker' of the already extremely well known Italian master Fellini (who even had accepted ,exceptionally, to act a brief role in Mazursky's second effort "Alex in Wonderland",in 1971,also very good), Mazursky was truly and rightly so,i'd like to add, just in love, with so many European classic directors,and their innovative new languages,that broke all the older movie making traditions,throughout the 1960's,bringing to us all,a more modern and authentic Cinema.Too badly,that,after Blume,and the still solid,if dated,"An unmarried woman"(back in 1979 a huge success),Mazursky tried to still make personal films(like the wonderfully melancholic and insightful,"Willie and Phil",which was not very well received,and,sadly,very little seen,in 1981),however,then, opting for a handful of more traditional Studio's comedies,never memorable nor poignant,as his first works had been,instead,and has not been truly active in mainstream films,for,at least 20years,yet remaining popular,and,an influential Hollywood personality,whom,i believe,could have achieved a lot more indeed, but was probably badly influenced by the commercial politics of the Studios, in the 1980's, who virtually killed his genius."Blume in Love" is instead excellent, sophisticated, perfect,but, yet, a little dated,and, in fact, not truly memorable,even though it could and,maybe, should absolutely,be!My take is,that beside,depicting the leading female character, only almost as a victim of her husband's guilt and will,so,offending basically every woman with,a minimum of feminism,in herself,or,just some simple self respect,while,even most importantly,for me,and,especially, after having been told the original plans, it is the film's leads,who,if excellent,for sure,did not manage to keep throughout the years,an original star's power!In fact,if you'd watch the movie now,i mean, it's all way more about the supporting roles(Kristofferson,a great Marsha Mason,and,even,briefly, Shelley Winters in a delightful extended cameo)than,truly about, the not very well focused,nor much remembered,impressions and everlasting images,the 2 leads,should have been,instead,revealing in such a piece!Segal, despite having done excellent work in many great comedies (like the still wonderful "A touch of Class",in 1972,and,opposite Glenda Jackson),ended up making a whole lot of cheesy,even low budgeted,at times,definitely trite films,and, Susan Anspach,was and still is an intense and brilliant actor,but did not carry,in my opinion, that necessary flawless star's charisma, in a role like the one of such,Nina Blume,a Beverly Hills lady of the then new generation, belonging to a privileged upbringing,but, most of all, to the counterculture,as well,and,so,she should have been infusing throughout the film an allure of poetry and mystery,a mix of class and perfection,freedom and wisdom, making of it, almost..an haunting character,instead, of making of it, just a merely,and, barely'tolerable',one!When i was told, and, this is very much true,not gossip,that,those roles had been offered, and, virtually accepted, by the then lovers,those two stars,making one of Hollywood's most incredible,sophisticated,clever,truly dreamy couples ever,i am talking about the likes of Warren Beatty and Julie Christie, who,nonetheless,again, i have been told, but, also read in many publications,had been attached to make this film,and,for quite a while,until when, Beatty(also convincing, supposedly, the stunning Christie, who would have made for a superb and incredibly more profound Nina,with all the owed respect to Anspach!)decided to opt out of the project (he was notoriously picky,and did never like to work a whole lot,loosing some truly great opportunities,like this one, while, also, damaging Christie's career, as well..maybe!)and,so then, Segal came to mind,after the huge success of "A touch of Class",while, after Christie's exit,and supposedly, both Natalie Wood and Bissett having passed on,also committing a great mistake, Mazursky had to cast,in order to prevent the project,to come to an halt, the excellent Anspach,who has never been,though, so much of a charismatic star,really,nor became one, with this great opportunity and vehicle!Somehow,this is for me,today, at least, the main flaw of,otherwise, a wonderfully visual,sophisticated,bitter sweet romantic comedy,about a hip Beverly Hills lawyer, whom we immediately meet while he remembers, all the back and forth's, of the romance of his own life and times, from a Cafe, in gloriously photographed,Venice,Italy -we'll find out- had also been the romantic place,of his magical honeymoon years before,when the wonderful marriage with the extraordinarily fascinating Nina,a new liberated,yet gorgeous,sensitive,classy beauty,had all started, so greatly, yet not able, who knows why ("Ah,c'est la vie!"The French would say..)preventing him from,and,by chance,cheating on her,and,eventually, quickly loosing her,and, for good,too,while, she'll actually firmly move on from him,transitioning into a new,and way more (for her,at least) suitable life, remaining also, always clear over her own wisdom and self esteem!He'll spend,instead,the rest of his life,trying to get her desperately back,in many funny,if disrespectful,even almost offensive(for today's standards,anyway!)situations: but,even more sadly, she always seems - other very clever choice for the script,especially back then,but, yet,not well conveyed,by Anspach's performance- always very understanding,over all of those pathetic situations, her ex husband seems to face,and, maybe, because,truly having moved on,she just seems to find him "sweet",without ever being capable to truly hate someone she had loved,at some point,so much,and, perhaps,even, believing,with an extremely evolved choice,that, maybe,at last,her and her ex husband Blume,could even become,simply,just.. friends! Or not??I won't spoil the end,for you,but,i bet(if you are,at least 35,or,a lover of the greater Cinema of those days,like myself!) you can imagine easily, what Beatty and Christie,at their very peak,could have done,with such a story and incredibly poignant material!Nonetheless,again,"Blume" remains a wonderfully crafted,executed,creative,and very,very entertaining, bitter sweet film,that, I recommend to everyone,with.. love!

reviewText: Mazursky made such great light intelligent comedies about relationships. Segal, Kristoferson and Anspach are all at their best. It's a sweet movie. The scenes in Venice are great. The direction is spot on. It's just about a perfect movie to watch with a girlfriend. I loved it and it brought back memories of the 'after' hippies, not quite sure what to do after that moment passed. Blume was in love.

reviewText: Well acted (I like George Segal) and nice scenes in Venice, but the movie is much too long, some scenes should have been removed with no loss at all, and plot line at the end is poorly written, I think.

reviewText: Paul Mazursky has always made films that are timeless.  The subject matter and uniqueness of his screenplays leave an owner of a copy of such films as "Blume in Love," happy to have a good old standby to watch a couple of times a year.  This film has a rare and terrific appearance of Kris Kristofferson.  I never understood why he hasn't been in at least 100 films, he's so likable and natural, and has a slow, simmering lethality that is always just out of sight, ready to explode when needed, often surprisingly since he is naturally so lay back.  Another actor who turns in an excellent performance in Susan Anspach and she is, or was, also a diamond in the rough.  George Segal gives us a satisfying George Segal character, but Shelley Winters will definitely crack you up.Paul Mazursky remains one of my all time favorite writer-producer-directors.  Check out his other films.  You'll be glad you did.
summary: Still great after all these years

reviewerName: Stephen H. Wood "Film scholar and vintage mov...
reviewText: When I was a college student in 1970's Los Angeles, I fell in love with Paul Mazursky's bittersweet BLUME IN LOVE (1973).  It is now on DVD, and I recommend it to all romantics of the world.  Beverly Hills divorce lawyer Stephen Blume (George Segal in a career-best performance) finds himself getting divorced from wife Nina (Susan Anspach) when he stupidly cheats on her with his secretary.  Blume befriends a sweet woman named Arlene (Marsha Mason), but still loves Nina.  But she now has a hippie boyfriend named Elmo (Kris Kristofferson, who made PAT GARRETT AND BILLY THE KID the same year).  Nina met Elmo in a Los Angeles welfare office, where she works.  Blume befriends Elmo to try and get to Nina.  She keeps telling Blume to get lost, but secretly misses him also.This is an extraordinarily insightful and superbly acted movie about human relationships and divorce.  The dialogue is wonderful.  ("I've seen GONE WITH THE WIND eleven times because I know it will be good."  "I raped my ex-wife, and her boyfriend beat me up.")  Writer/director Mazursky gives it an interesting structure, beginning and ending in Venice (Italy) with a bearded Blume sipping expresso in an open plaza and watching people around him.  They are in love, and he misses Nina.  In flashback, we learn how the two met and married in Venice, moved to Los Angeles, then several years later how they got divorced in Las Vegas.  And we learn how Blume meets Arlene, who kind of resents having him always talking and thinking about Nina during sex.  On the other hand, Nina claims she never thinks of Blume after the divorce.  That's not true, as the last couple of reels reveal.  I personally find the last scene optimistic, but still true-to-life.Watching a wonderful Sidney Poitier drama called TO SIR, WITH LOVE (1967), I told myself it could only take place in 1967 London because of the character relationships, the dialogue, and the city.  Watching BLUME IN LOVE, which was photographed by Bruce Surtees and designed by Pato Guzman, I told myself it is a time capsule of my college heyday in 1973 Los Angeles.  I was 22.  If it was released in Spring, I was graduating from UCLA; if it was a Fall release, I was just starting at USC's School of Cinema.  The characters bed one another freely without condoms in a pre-AIDS age and say "the f--- word" often enough to get an "R" rating; and they smoke pot and use the expression "my old lady" for girl friends.BLUME IN LOVE is definitely a 1970's movie, one of the finest.  I gets 1973 Los Angeles just right, down to the details.  I highly recommend it to adult moviegoers.
summary: A bitttersweet 1970's Los Angeles romance for adults
